item.title: China’s Private Factory Gauge Plunges to Weakest Since 2022
item.description: China’s manufacturing sector had its worst slump since September 2022, according to a private survey, as higher US tariffs took a toll on smaller exporters despite a truce in the trade war with the US.
item.dc:creator: Lucille Liu

media:content.media:description: Photo by Li Chaoqing/China News Service/VCG via Getty Images)

item.title: South Korea Votes for New Leader to Heal Nation, Spur Growth
item.description: South Koreans head to the polls Tuesday to elect a new president after an attempt to impose martial law at the end of last year triggered its worst constitutional crisis in decades.
item.dc:creator: Soo-Hyang Choi, Heesu Lee

media:content.media:description: A voter casts their ballot at a polling station in Incheon, South Korea. Photographer: SeongJoon Cho/Bloomberg

item.title: RBA Opts for Quarter-Point Cut to Navigate Uncertain Outlook
item.description: Australia’s central bank discussed the case to cut interest rates by an outsized half-percentage point last month, highlighting that a larger reduction would provide greater insurance for the economy against any major US-led trade upheaval.
item.dc:creator: Swati Pandey

media:content.media:description: Pedestrians with an umbrella walk past the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) headquarters in the central business district of Sydney, Australia, on Thursday, June 21, 2018. Australia is riding out a huge gamble on property. The bet: 27 years of recession-free economic growth—during which Sydney home prices surged fivefold—would continue unabated and allow borrowers to keep servicing their debt.

item.title: BOJ’s Ueda Hints at Chance of Continuing to Cut Bond Purchases
item.description: Bank of Japan Governor Kazuo Ueda hinted that the central bank could continue to slow the pace of government bond purchases next fiscal year, as the board’s decision over bond buying approaches.
item.dc:creator: Toru Fujioka

media:content.media:description: Kazuo Ueda Photographer: Toru Hanai/Bloomberg

item.title: RBA’s Hunter Sees US Tariffs Dragging on Australian Growth, Jobs
item.description: Australia’s central bank expects global trade uncertainty will weigh on the domestic economy and employment, according to a senior official, helping explain policymakers’ surprise switch to a dovish stance last month.
item.dc:creator: Swati Pandey

media:content.media:description: Sarah Hunter, chief economist and assistant governor of Reserve Bank of Australia, during the Financial Review Banking Summit in Sydney, Australia, on Tuesday, March 18, 2025. The summit runs through today. Photographer: Brent Lewin/Bloomberg

item.title: Chinese Firms Warn EU Procurement Curb Could Hurt Trade Ties
item.description: A Chinese business lobby group warned that EU actions to curb access of the country’s medical device makers to government contracts in the bloc will hurt trade ties.
item.dc:creator: Colum Murphy

media:content.media:description: A worker checks parts at a factory which produces medical endoscope lenses in Hangzhou, in China's eastern Zhejiang province on October 31, 2024. China's manufacturing output expanded this month for the first time since April, official data showed on October 31, rare good news for leaders struggling to boost activity in the world's second-largest economy. (Photo by AFP) / China OUT (Photo by STR/AFP via Getty Images) Photographer: STR/AFP

item.title: Carney Open to New Canada Oil Pipeline Tied to Carbon Capture
item.description: Mark Carney said he sees opportunity for Canada to build a new pipeline to ship more oil to foreign markets, if it’s tied to billions in green investments to reduce the industry’s environmental footprint.
item.dc:creator: Brian Platt, Thomas Seal

media:content.media:description: The Port of Prince Rupert in Prince Rupert, British Columbia. One project being pitched by premiers is an economic corridor running from the western port to Churchill, Manitoba.

item.title: BOJ Likely to End Bond Purchase Cuts Next Year, Ex-Official Says
item.description: The Bank of Japan will probably decide to stop reducing the amount of its government bond purchases in a plan for next fiscal year when authorities gather this month, as they eye a worrisome surge in JGB yields, according to a former BOJ board member.
item.dc:creator: Toru Fujioka, Sumio Ito

media:content.media:description: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) headquarters in Tokyo, Japan, on Thursday, Dec. 19, 2024. The Bank of Japan kept its monetary policy settings steady as it bides its time for now, while a dissenter's proposed rate hike suggests momentum for another increase is building.

item.title: BOE’s Mann Warns of Tension Between Rate Cuts and Gilt Sales
item.description: Bank of England rate-setter Catherine Mann said there’s a tension between cuts to interest rates and efforts to unwind quantitative easing, warning her colleagues that bond sales risk stunting the economy by holding up long-dated yields.
item.dc:creator: Tom Rees

media:content.media:description: Catherine Mann, member of the monetary policy committee at the Bank of England (BOE), during a Bloomberg Television interview in London, UK, on Tuesday, March 7, 2023. Mann said the pound could weaken further in the coming months as investors absorb the implication of the US Federal Reserve and European Central Bank’s plans to raise interest rates. Photographer: Hollie Adams/Bloomberg

item.title: For Volatile Trump, Trade Pacts With China, Europe Prove Elusive
item.description: US President Donald Trump is eager to land more trade deals, but talks with China and Europe continue to languish amid communications breakdowns and fresh tariff threats.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Lucey

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump walks on the South Lawn of the White House before boarding Marine One in Washington, DC, US, on Friday, May 30, 2025. Trump accused China of violating an agreement with the US to ease tariffs, ratcheting up tensions between the world's two largest economies.

item.title: Saudi Arabia’s Hurdles at Home Are Reshaping the Mideast Financial Order
item.description: Bankers and business leaders are shifting more attention toward the kingdom’s neighbors in the Gulf as it grapples with lower oil prices and weakening finances.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Martin, Dinesh Nair, Adveith Nair

media:content.media:description: Saudi Arabia needs to bring in foreign capital to continue spending.

item.title: Mexico Remittances Plunge as Trump Cracks Down on Migrants
item.description: Remittances sent to Mexico fell 12% in April from a year prior, registering the largest annual drop in more than a decade as US lawmakers mull taxing the transfers and Donald Trump’s administration toughens its rhetoric against migrants.
item.dc:creator: Alex Vasquez

media:content.media:description: Customers at a money exchange outside the US Customs and Border Protection - San Ysidro Port of Entry in San Diego, California.

item.title: Trump Team Pushes for Xi Call as Trade Tensions Simmer
item.description: US President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping are likely to speak this week, the White House said, as the world’s two largest economies remain locked in trade turmoil.
item.dc:creator: Josh Wingrove

media:content.media:description: Donald Trump and Xi Jinping Photographer: Bonnie Cash/UPI and Michele Spatari/Bloomberg

item.title: Milei’s FX Gambit Sparks Sharpest Demand for Dollars Since 2019
item.description: Demand for dollars in Argentina hit its highest since 2019 after President Javier Milei all but eliminated foreign-exchange restrictions in the crisis-prone South American nation.
item.dc:creator: Manuela Tobias

item.title: Fed’s Goolsbee Says Rates Can Fall If Trade Policy Is Resolved
item.description: Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago President Austan Goolsbee reiterated the US economy looks good underneath the surface, and the central bank can proceed with interest-rate cuts if uncertainty around trade policy is resolved.
item.dc:creator: Catarina Saraiva

media:content.media:description: Austan Goolsbee, president and chief executive officer of the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago, speaks during the Midwest Agriculture Conference at the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago in Chicago, Illinois, US, on Tuesday, Nov. 28, 2023. Federal Reserve officials this month welcomed the latest data showing receding US inflation, while adding that there's still a way to go before it reaches the central bank's 2% target. Photographer: Vincent Alban/Bloomberg

item.title: Logan Says Fed Can Wait as Risks to Inflation, Jobs Are Balanced
item.description: Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas President Lorie Logan said the US central bank can remain patient as it assesses risks to both inflation and unemployment.
item.dc:creator: Maria Eloisa Capurro

media:content.media:description: Lorie Logan

item.title: German Banks Pay Millions to Settle Claims by Insolvent Signa
item.description: Helaba and other German lenders have paid millions of euros in recent weeks to settle claims by the administrator of former real estate tycoon Rene Benko’s Signa Prime Selection AG.
item.dc:creator: Marton Eder

media:content.media:description: Hoardings with the Signa logo around a shopping center in Munich, Germany in March 2024.

item.title: US Manufacturing Activity Contracted in May for a Third Month
item.description: US factory activity contracted in May for a third consecutive month and a gauge of imports fell to a 16-year low as firms pulled back in the face of higher tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Nazmul Ahasan

media:content.media:description: A worker arc welds a metal door during production at the Metal Manufacturing Co. facility in Sacramento, California, US, on Tuesday, May 27, 2025. The US Census Bureau is scheduled to release factory orders figures on June 3.

item.title: Matthei Gives Chile Vote Pledges a Reality Check on Fiscal Woes
item.description: Faced with an electoral campaign fought on two fronts — against the left and the hard right — Chile’s presidential front-runner Evelyn Matthei is trying to mark a difference not through sweeping promises, but by recognizing the cold, hard facts of a weak economy.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Malinowski

media:content.media:description: Presidential candidate for the Independent Democratic Union party, Evelyn Matthei, speaks during an event in Santiago, Chile, on May 19.

item.title: Chile’s Economic Growth Triples Forecast as Mining Surges
item.description: Chile’s economy grew more than expected in April as mining output jumped, offsetting a drop in manufacturing and retail, according to the central bank’s main gauge of monthly activity.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Malinowski

media:content.media:description: A copper mine and processing facility in Machali, Chile.

item.title: Philippines Aims to Cut Reliance on Vietnam for Rice
item.description: The Philippines, the world’s top rice importer, plans to look beyond its dominant supplier, Vietnam, to ensure steady supplies and competitive prices at home.
item.dc:creator: Neil Jerome Morales, Cliff Harvey Venzon

item.title: Romania Injects More Funds to Banks as Market Shortage Narrows
item.description: Romania’s central bank injected liquidity into domestic banks for a second week as it sought to further calm money markets after increased volatility during recent political turmoil.
item.dc:creator: Andra Timu

media:content.media:description: The headquarters of Romania's central bank in Bucharest. Photographer: Andrei Pungovschi/Bloomberg

item.title: Risks Abound If Trump Ties Tariffs to a Balance-of-Payments Crisis
item.description: Countries tend to avoid declaring they’re facing balance-of-payments problems, for good reason. They unnerve markets. They remind people of policy failures in places like Argentina, Greece or Thailand. They conjure up images of IMF technocrats flying in to enforce austerity regimes.
item.dc:creator: Shawn Donnan

item.title: It’s Not Just Trump Vs Harvard as Global Universities Turn Inward
item.description: I’m Malcolm Scott, international economics editor in Sydney. Today, Swati Pandey looks at the international student market. Send us feedback and tips to ecodaily@bloomberg.net. And if you aren’t yet signed up to receive this newsletter, you can do so here.
item.dc:creator: Swati Pandey

item.title: Chile’s Long Road to CPI Target Sees Peso Bonds Back in Favor
item.description: Investors are exiting Chilean inflation-linked bonds in favor of instruments denominated in pesos on confidence that CPI is on track to hit the target in early 2026 for the first time in more than five years.
item.dc:creator: Carolina Gonzalez

media:content.media:description: Shoppers at the Plaza de Armas in Santiago, Chile.

item.title: Carney Aims to Thwart Trump’s Tariff Assault by Unlocking Internal Trade
item.description: Prime Minister Mark Carney is pushing to offset the economic pain caused by US President Donald Trump’s tariffs by compelling Canadian provinces to liberalize trade with one another.
item.dc:creator: Erik Hertzberg

item.title: UK House Prices Post Surprise Increase in May, Nationwide Says
item.description: UK house prices unexpectedly rose in May, in a sign that demand for housing remains resilient following the expiry of a tax break for buyers, according to one of Britain’s largest mortgage lenders.
item.dc:creator: Irina Anghel

media:content.media:description: Homes in London. Photographer: Hollie Adams/Bloomberg

item.title: Putin’s Central Banker Under Fire to Cut Record-High Rates
item.description: The Bank of Russia’s governor, who was praised for helping save the country’s economy after the invasion of Ukraine, is facing mounting pressure to reverse course on record-high borrowing costs amid worries over their toll on business.
item.dc:creator: Ben Sills

media:content.media:description: Bank of Russia governor Elvira Nabiullina Photographer: Olga Maltseva/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Japan to Seek $840 Billion of Inward Foreign Investment by 2030
item.description: Japan plans to raise its incoming foreign direct investment target to ¥120 trillion ($840 billion) by 2030, aiming to attract more overseas capital to help revitalize struggling regional economies and address labor shortages.
item.dc:creator: Erica Yokoyama

item.title: Madagascar Courts UAE Investment to Offset US Tariff Threat
item.description: Madagascar is seeking to boost investments from the United Arab Emirates to spur growth in its tourism and energy sectors, a partnership that’s become more urgent as its faces steep tariffs from the US.
item.dc:creator: Dana Khraiche

media:content.media:description: Workers process vanilla pods following a harvest in Madagascar. Photographer: Rijasolo/AFP/Getty Images
